p:
An early degradation of IRF3 and other molecules regulating pathogen recognition could lead to impaired IFN responses during ZIKV infection. In addition of blocking IFN signaling via NS5-mediated degradation of STAT2, several studies have reported an inhibition of RLR signaling suggesting another evasion strategy for ZIKV. With promoter-reporter assays some ZIKV proteins, especially that of NS5 have been associated with an inhibition of IFN gene expression
42, 44 . NS1 and NS4B have also been reported to inhibit RLR-mediated IFN gene expression by inhibiting the phosphorylation of TBK1 and IRF3
49 . Thus, the exact molecular mechanisms by which ZIKV is interfering with IFN induction and IFN signaling still needs further analysis in order to understand the pathogenicity of ZIKV and identifying the targets for therapeutic interventions in severe ZIKV infections.
